Opinion Finding Beauty

Underneath Paris

By Katie Kitamura Visuals by Lee Mary Manning

Aug. 8, 2025

This essay is part of Finding Beauty, a series
on discovering joy in the unexpected.

There is a grate on Rue Danton in Paris, not too far from the university campus where I teach during the summer, that emits a particular smell: sweet, a touch rubbery and a little industrial.

It’s the smell of the Paris Métro. I remember it from one particular summer that I spent in Paris as a teenager.

That summer I spent the day at an office in the suburbs, proofreading English language translations of technical papers.

I didn’t make any close friends; the office was filled with kind people who were decades older than I was, and I knew no one else in the city.

I lived in a chambre de bonne, with a shared toilet in the hall and a shower patched into the corner. The room was too small to spend very much time in, so I was propelled out every evening.

I would ride the Métro to different stops, scattered across the city and chosen nearly at random: Magenta, Oberkampf, Les Gobelins.

I would emerge out into the lamp-lit streets, walk quickly but without purpose, and then ride the Métro back home again.

I had never spent much time in any city before, and those nights riding the train were the first time I understood how a metropolis allows you to be solitary without being lonely.

Solitude and independence were new sensations for me. I wanted for nothing. I don’t mean that simply in the material sense.

Walking on the street or riding the Métro, inhabiting the city — in these experiences, in these moments, all my longings were met.

As I edged my way into adulthood, I learned to want more — from the world, from my relationships, from myself.

The scope of my longing grew wider, and with it came a more complex sense of need. I was also never quite so alone again.

The following summer I returned to Paris with three friends from college, and we shared an apartment, and we went to bars and nightclubs and celebrated on the street when France won the World Cup.

I don’t recall noticing the smell of the Métro.

Now, when I stumble upon the Métro smell, I’m flung back to that first summer with surprising force.

I find myself face to face with aspects of the city and myself from years earlier, the feeling so immediate it feels like teleportation.

I recall — I experience again — what it’s like to be so intensely absorbed in the present that both the future and the past are no source of trouble or excitement. It’s like stepping into a protective bubble, a momentary enclosure.

Sadly, this olfactory time travel happens less and less frequently. Even as I seek it out, the smell, once ubiquitous, has by and large disappeared.

The other day I stepped onto the platform at Poissonnière and there it was, at least for a few seconds. But it’s no longer pervasive in the way it once was.

Fortunately, there is that grate on Rue Danton. I always slow a little when I pass.

Paris is, of course, a place that was very much created with intent. So many elements of the city have a purpose — to display beauty or power, to seduce or intimidate or impose order.

But the subway smell — synthetic, oddly pleasant — has no particular purpose. It is, I think, simply byproduct. And perhaps that’s where its beauty lies for me.

This useless and mysterious phenomenon catapults me through time and space, and in it I remember pieces of the city, and pieces of myself, from many decades ago.

Katie Kitamura’s most
recent novel is "Audition."

Lee Mary Manning is an artist
living in New York City.

Published August 8, 2025.
